metadata.analysis_scope: Argumentative patterns, framework introduction, refutation techniques, evidence types, logical flow

argumentative_structures.template: Start with critique of vague/abstract concept → demand operational definition → introduce systematic alternative with concrete mechanics
argumentative_structures.example: He critiques 'vibrar alto' (high vibration) as vague spiritual language → reveals the hidden assumption (self-superiority) → reframes through emosocial lens as contextual vulnerability → proposes concrete action (ask what the person needs) instead of abstract judgment
argumentative_structures.direct_quote: Vibrar bajo es alguien que se está quejando... tú dices 'vibra abajo.' Y es como si de alguna manera tú ya te posicionas como que alguien que vibra alto... Entonces, ya al tú juzgar desde vibrar alto, eh, que el otro vibra abajo, tú ya te estás volviendo en vibrar bajo.
argumentative_structures.underlying_mechanism: Reveals hidden assumptions in popular concepts by showing how applying them creates the opposite effect

argumentative_structures.template: Challenge trait-based labeling → show how context/interaction determines the trait → demonstrate that same person shows opposite trait in different context → conclude trait is contextual, not essential
argumentative_structures.example: TDAH diagnosis: Claims adolescents labeled with TDAH in classroom context are 'hyperactive' → but he shows how same adolescent focuses perfectly when taught differently → proves TDAH is interaction-dependent (student + boring teacher + lack_of_motivation), not a fixed trait
argumentative_structures.direct_quote: Chavales que están diagnosticados con TDAH... en clase con un profesor delante pues sí... pero es que yo delante de un profesor también soy TDAH... pero de repente yo saco a ese adolescente de ahí... lo pongo en otro contexto a aprender lo mismo de otra manera y se concentra mucho más.
argumentative_structures.underlying_mechanism: Identity = Interaction framework: proves that what seems like personal traits are actually emergent properties of the person-context relationship

argumentative_structures.template: Accept the popular framework's premise → chain consequences through multiple contingencies → show cascade failure → reveal framework's hidden assumption (single factor causality)
argumentative_structures.example: Purpose of life discourse chain: 'If purpose = abundance' → Person pursues expensive degree with purpose → borrows 200,000 EUR → business fails → ends homeless under bridge → reveals that 'having purpose' alone doesn't guarantee abundance (depends on market conditions, capital access, timing, etc.)
argumentative_structures.direct_quote: Si tú tienes tu propósito de vida, voy a pedir un crédito al banco de 200,000 EUR... abres la empresa, no funciona, tienes banca rota... acabas viviendo debajo un puente... Ese discurso te da un alivio... pero no significa que porque tengas un propósito de vida te vaya a salir la vida de... madre.
argumentative_structures.underlying_mechanism: Exposes single-factor bias: shows that complex outcomes depend on multiple factors, not just mindset or purpose

argumentative_structures.template: Show individual unit as 'dumb/ineffective' in isolation → demonstrate emergent property at scale (collective level) → map individual back to collective context → conclude individual agency is overestimated
argumentative_structures.example: Ant metaphor: Single ant = follows pheromone trails (appears dumb) → 1 million ants = create sophisticated colony intelligence → humans are ants creating complex collective moral/social systems → individuals mistakenly try to apply collective intelligence individually → results in confused/contradictory behavior
argumentative_structures.direct_quote: Una hormiga por sí sola, no hace mucho... Lo único que hace es seguir las feromonas de la de adelante... Pero eh lo que sucede es que cuando juntas a un millón de hormigas crean una especie de inteligencia, ¿vale? ...somos como individuos torpes al querer eh aplicar, digamos, eso que hemos creado como inteligencia colectiva.
argumentative_structures.underlying_mechanism: Emergentism: demonstrates that individual minds are too simple to understand complex social systems; this creates perpetual misalignment between intention and effect

argumentative_structures.template: Observe behavioral change → point out person's post-hoc narrative → name the mechanism (reconstructive memory) → show how mechanism justifies changed identity
argumentative_structures.example: Employee becomes entrepreneur: Was unhappy as employee → starts business → business succeeds → claims 'I found my purpose' → Actually: reconstructive memory modifying past narrative to match current success and identity (entrepreneur, not employee)
argumentative_structures.direct_quote: De repente dice, 'Ah, y ahí volvemos a la memoria reconstructiva y al sesgo de continuación.' De alguna manera modificas la interpretación de tu historia, del pasado, para crear un sentido de vida que encaje con la identidad que tienes ahora.
argumentative_structures.underlying_mechanism: Demonstrates how humans retrofit meaning onto their past to maintain identity coherence in present

argumentative_structures.template: Identify a habitual behavior → ask when was it actually tested/verified → reveal that person assumes necessity without evidence → propose behavioral experiment (withdrawal) → likely discover it's inertia, not necessity
argumentative_structures.example: Coffee dependency: Person says 'Without coffee I'm nobody' → But when did they last not drink coffee to verify? → Probably never → So belief is inertia/addiction to self-image, not actual necessity → Can test by skipping coffee and observing actual effects vs. perceived effects
argumentative_structures.direct_quote: Yo es que sin café eh no soy nadie, necesito café para ser alguien. Y claro, dices, eh, ¿cuánto hace que no tomas café para darte cuenta de que te sirve para ser alguien? ...hace mucho tiempo que tomo café, entonces tampoco he probado qué pasa si no tomo café.
argumentative_structures.underlying_mechanism: Cognitive bias: we identify with behaviors and assume withdrawal = identity loss, without testing the assumption

argumentative_structures.template: Identify a single trait/behavior in specific context → show person generalizing to whole identity → name mechanism (alloe effect) → demonstrate trait varies by context → conclude: don't take part for whole
argumentative_structures.example: Being 'stupid': Person bad at math (specific context) → generalizes to 'I'm stupid' (whole identity) → but might excel at music, mechanics, social dynamics → stupidity is contextual, not global trait; shouldn't identity with global label from local failure
argumentative_structures.direct_quote: Eres tonto, pero igual no eres tonto en tu globalidad, eres tonto en una cosa específica, pues eh en una situación concreta... Entonces, eh darnos cuenta que también el efecto alo es lo de tomar la parte por el todo.
argumentative_structures.underlying_mechanism: Humans mistake situation-specific skill variations for global character traits, then identify with the limiting label

argumentative_structures.template: Identify popular single-factor explanation → list actual factors determining outcome → show single factor is necessary but not sufficient → conclude framework is oversimplified
argumentative_structures.example: Life outcome attribution: Saying 'Purpose determines success' ignores: market conditions, capital, timing, luck, education, family resources, health, geography, etc. Single-factor frameworks create false hope and misplaced blame (if you fail, you lack purpose/faith)
argumentative_structures.direct_quote: Volvemos al sesgo de factor único... parece que ya si tienes un propósito ya la vida está hecha... No, pero hay mucho esfuerzo, sí, claro, hay esfuerzo, pero igual que si no tengo un propósito también, pues no hay esfuerzo.
argumentative_structures.underlying_mechanism: Complex systems thinking: exposes how reductionist thinking creates both false hope and inappropriate blame

argumentative_structures.template: Acknowledge person's belief/emotion as valid response to their context → show how denying it creates more suffering → propose accepting it while changing response → demonstrate this reduces reactivity
argumentative_structures.example: Accepting validation-seeking: Official discourse says 'don't seek validation' → But humans inherently need validation → Denying this need creates shame → Instead: accept 'I seek validation' → when refused, you're aware and less affected because not fighting your nature
argumentative_structures.direct_quote: Hay muchos conceptos que es mejor eh decir, pues sí, busco validación, entonces cuando no la recibo, soy consciente y entonces me afecta menos... Cuanto más asumo que soy alguien torpe, pues menos me creo lo que me me diga cualquier persona.
argumentative_structures.underlying_mechanism: Paradoxical framework: accepting 'flaws' creates freedom because you stop fighting your nature

argumentative_structures.template: Describe individualist approach (isolation, judgment, avoidance) → show it maintains problem (reinforces behavior) → present collaborative alternative (ask needs, create safe space, reinterpret together) → show how it disrupts pattern
argumentative_structures.example: Energy vampire reframe: Individualist says 'avoid person who complains' (isolation) → But they're in your workspace → So you both stay stuck → Collaborative: 'What do you need?' → Creates psychological safety → person opens up → you learn about their vulnerability → shared understanding shifts dynamic
argumentative_structures.direct_quote: Si tú estás dentro de mi entorno laboral o familiar, pues tío, vamos a echar un buen rato... Vamos a hacer lo mejor que sea para los dos... El vampiro energético, ¿por qué es un vampiro energético? Pues porque no le estás diciendo lo que piensas de él.
argumentative_structures.underlying_mechanism: Collective intelligence principle: isolation maintains individual-level problems; collective problem-solving requires vulnerability and shared meaning-making

argumentative_structures.template: Identify abstract psychological concept from popular discourse → show how abstraction creates confusion/false expectation → translate to concrete observable mechanics → propose concrete metric for verification
argumentative_structures.example: Emotion vs. Thought confusion: Discourse says 'feel your authentic self' (abstract) → People expect specific feeling → Don't achieve it → conclude they're broken → Concrete version: 'you think a thought about yourself → that thought creates a feeling' → Empirically verifiable, actionable
argumentative_structures.direct_quote: Estamos en un mundo que te dice cómo buscar tu se auténtico... Eso solo obtienes más frustración, más presión y la falsa idea de que algo está mal contigo... No estás roto, tío... Yo me pienso culpable y me siento mal... es más que nada lo que te hace sentir es un pensamiento.
argumentative_structures.underlying_mechanism: Demystification: translates abstract psychology into mechanistic observable processes to make it actionable and remove shame

personal_clinical_observations.description: Direct observations from his work with teenagers in institutes and at-risk youth
examples: TDAH diagnosis varies by context (same student focuses in different teaching environment)
Narcissism emerges from bullying/abandonment, not fixed personality
Energy vampires respond to direct inquiry about needs

neuroscience_references.description: References to brain structures and evolutionary psychology
examples: Amígdala (primitive emotional response) vs. Prefrontal cortex (reasoning)
Evolutionary mismatch: collective intelligence creation vs. individual cognitive capacity
Critique of Law of Attraction (single-factor bias)
Analysis of how moral systems become 'hypnotic' cultural programming

systematic_observations.description: Pattern observation without formal research (grounded observation)

thought_experiments.description: Hypothetical scenarios to expose logical inconsistencies
examples: Purpose + expensive loan + failed business = homelessness (consequence chain)
Abandoning grandmother to start aspiration business (moral reductio)
City of God shooting example (showing intent vs. context causality)

premise_reasoning_conclusion.example: Observation: People say 'without coffee I'm nobody' | Mechanism: Behavioral inertia + identity fusion | Implication: Belief is untested assumption | Reframe: Can verify through experimentation

reductio_ad_absurdum.structure: Accept premise → follow chain of consequences → reveal absurd/harmful outcome → reject premise
reductio_ad_absurdum.example: Premise: 'Purpose attracts abundance' → accepts premise → chains consequences (loan, business failure, homelessness, grandmother abandoned) → reveals harm → concludes single-factor thinking is dangerous
reductio_ad_absurdum.function: Exposes hidden assumptions in popular frameworks

comparative_analysis.structure: Show two contexts/framings of same phenomenon → contrast outcomes → identify decisive variable → conclude contextual determination
comparative_analysis.example: TDAH: Classroom (diagnosed ADHD) vs. Alternative teaching (focused) → variable = teaching method × motivation match → concludes trait is interaction-dependent

scale_bridge.structure: Individual level analysis → scale to collective level → re-interpret individual behavior as collective pattern → conclude mutual entailment
scale_bridge.example: Individual belief → millions holding same belief → creates cultural moral system → individuals then confused trying to apply collective intelligence individually

paradoxical_reversal.structure: Identify recommended approach → show it creates opposite effect → propose opposite → show it works
paradoxical_reversal.example: Recommended: 'Don't seek validation' → Creates shame of validation-seeking → Paradox: Accept 'I seek validation' → Results in less reactivity to refusal

addressing_counter_arguments.method: Acknowledge validity of concern → show it's based on false assumption → reframe with additional factors
addressing_counter_arguments.example: Counter: 'But if the person doesn't change?' | Response: 'Yes, there's a process, and if they don't change, you can also choose to leave—that's not failure, that's adaptation'

concession_with_boundary.method: Concede valid point (person resistant to change exists) → immediately establish scope boundary (pathological cases, uncontrollable factors) → show boundary is narrow
concession_with_boundary.example: Concedes: Some people with schizophrenia can't change via interaction alone | Boundary: But only when neurological/tumor-based | Scope: Most behavioral patterns remain interaction-dependent

reframing_objections.method: Take objection as valid observation → show it's partial perspective → embed in larger system → show larger system resolves apparent contradiction
reframing_objections.example: Objection: 'Isn't it cruel to not convince religious family members they're wrong?' | Reframe: 'You're already trying to convince them (primitive amygdala response) → larger system: cultural evolution takes time → humane approach: validate while maintaining boundaries'

mechanism_exposure.method: When objecting, don't argue the point—expose the mechanism creating the objection
mechanism_exposure.example: Person says 'I searched for authentic self but couldn't find it' → Don't debate authenticity → Expose mechanism: 'The discourse created false expectation of a feeling you should have, so you concluded you're broken—that's the mechanism creating your confusion'

pragmatic_acceptance.method: Don't fight ideology directly → propose acceptance + different response → show empirical results
pragmatic_acceptance.example: To evangelical family member: Don't argue theology → Acknowledge 'I see you're suggesting divine purpose' → Your response: 'Yes, maybe, in any case, I'm handling my life this way' → Result: Relationship preserved, boundaries maintained, less conflict

vulnerability_centering.description: All behavior traced to basic vulnerability (fear, need for belonging, validation-seeking, mortality awareness) rather than character or will
vulnerability_centering.strategic_function: Removes shame and blame, enables compassion for all actors

identity_equals_interaction_formula.description: Core theoretical frame: identity is not essential trait but emergent property of person × context interaction
identity_equals_interaction_formula.strategic_function: Explains why traits seem to change; explains why diagnoses are context-dependent

evolutionary_stage_awareness.description: Frames human conflict/confusion as normal stage of evolutionary development (prefrontal cortex not yet sophisticated enough to apply collective intelligence)
evolutionary_stage_awareness.strategic_function: Reduces taking things personally; normalizes failure; increases patience

mechanism_over_morality.description: Consistently redirects from moral judgment (good/bad behavior) to mechanistic explanation (what conditions generated the behavior)
mechanism_over_morality.example: Instead of 'Narcissist is bad' → 'Narcissism is adaptive response to abandonment/bullying; the mechanism is protection through dominance'
mechanism_over_morality.strategic_function: Preserves dignity while allowing understanding; enables intervention

abstraction_translation.description: Takes abstract psychological/spiritual concept and translates to observable, concrete mechanism
abstraction_translation.example: 'Feel your authentic self' → 'You think a thought about who you are → that thought creates a feeling'
abstraction_translation.strategic_function: Makes psychology actionable; removes false expectations; reduces shame

technical_vs_accessible.note: Sergio explicitly chooses accessible language over technical psychology jargon
technical_vs_accessible.quote: Podría hablar más técnico, pero es que si no entonces no me entero ni yo
technical_vs_accessible.strategy: Maintains accessibility while referencing scientific concepts (emergence, reconstructive memory, operant conditioning)

myth_vs_reality_juxtaposition.note: Contrasts popular spiritual/self-help narrative with mechanistic reality
myth_vs_reality_juxtaposition.example: Myth: 'Find your purpose and abundance will follow' | Reality: 'Purpose is contextual + temporary + depends on dozens of factors'
myth_vs_reality_juxtaposition.function: Relieves false hope and inappropriate blame

personal_example_disclosure.note: Uses own vulnerabilities and failures as teaching examples
examples: 'I was in conflict with evangelicals but eventually stopped fighting'
'I'm bad with some things but not everything' (part-whole effect)
'I also can't focus for 20 minutes in boring lectures'
personal_example_disclosure.function: Models vulnerability; demonstrates ownership of contradictions; builds trust

central_thesis_structure.core_claim:
All psychological suffering derives from:
1) Identifying with contextual traits as if they were essential
2) Internalizing collective cultural programming as if it were personal truth
3) Fighting one's own vulnerability instead of accepting it
central_thesis_structure.supporting_framework: Identity = Interaction (nothing essential; all emergent from person × context)
central_thesis_structure.practical_implication:
Liberation comes through:
- Accepting vulnerability (stops fighting self)
- Contextualizing traits (stops generalizing)
- Collective problem-solving (stops isolating)
central_thesis_structure.epistemological_stance: Don't believe anything (recognize all frameworks as partial) → Act based on contextual effectiveness → Maintain humility about complexity
